An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.

For a field $K$ of characteristic $p>0$, the map $\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$, which respects the addition on $K$, defines a homomorphism of fields known as the Frobenius homomorphism of $K$.
Does the concept of a/an Element of a Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Frobenius homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of an 'Element of a Set' is fundamental to understanding and defining any mathematical structure involving sets, including fields and homomorphisms. In the definition of the Frobenius homomorphism, the map 
$$\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$$
involves elements 'a' from the field 'K'. Here, 'a' is an element of the set 'K'. Without the concept of an element of a set, it would not be possible to define the function 
$$a \longmapsto a^{p}$$
as this function operates on elements of the set 'K'. Therefore, understanding what it means for 'a' to be an element of 'K' is crucial for the definition of the Frobenius homomorphism to make sense.
